projectDesc.p: This document is part of a larger digital collection of stories of ghost hoaxes from the 18th and 19th century London newspapers and periodicals. The project explores the beginnings of mass print media in a metropolitan area at a time when technology and education made reading increasingly common and inexpensive.

The corpus holds 36 individual documents, which reflect a diverse mix of reporting on various hauntings in and around London between 1804 and 1889. The PDF and JPEGs from online databases were transcribed using ABBYFineReader OCR, then corrected and occasionally manually transcribed if document quality necessitated it. After normalization in plain text, all documents were upconverted to TEI XML.

normalization.p: Earlier texts have had some spelling normalization due to errors in OCR. Typographic em dashes are longer than modern em dashes, so all dashes have been normalized to modern em dash length.

quotation.p: All extraneous white space used by printers to avoid overlapping with letters has been removed. All quotes are simply tagged with the q tag.

body.p: ﻿A respectable old gentleman, residing not many miles from the New Church,in the Strand, and certainly not very superstitious, was, in the course of the last week, alarmed by an extraordinary and mysterious noise in his house, for which he was, for some nights, unable to account, and which, at length, almost removed his scepticism on the subject of unearthly visitations to this world. While sitting reading, as was his practice, to a late hour, his attention was attracted by a noise, as he thought, of some person coming down stairs in slippers, conceiving it was his good lady, who had retired to rest, and who was coming to invite him to follow her example, or their servant, he called to know who was there? but received no answer. The noise being continued, and having actually passed his door, he rose, took the light, and renewed his enquiry on the landing place; but with as little success, No reply was made. He then mounted to his bed-chamber, awoke his wife, and in company with her and (the servant, & armed with a brace of pistols, searched every part of the premises for the supposed intruder, but without making any discovery. The same noise was repeated on the following night, but he was still unable to ascertain the cause. At length, determined to be on the watch, he placed himself in his room with the latch of the door in one hand, and a candle in the other. At the usual time the noise was repeated) and with no small trepidation our old friend cautiously peeped forth, and looked up the first flight of stairs, down which the slip shod ghost seemed to be coming. At first he could see nothing—probably from the disorganized state of his vision in such an alarming state of things; but at last he distinctly saw something small, but white, come hopping from step to step. It certainly had no earthly shape, and yet appeared to be gifted with a power of motion, which, as it approached him, encreased his alarm. He wished to speak, but either from the sudden inactivity of his organs of speech, or from not knowing exactly what to say to so questionable a visitor, he could not utter a word—when, wound up to a pitch of extraordinary excitation, his doubts and his fears were at once allayed by observing that the cause of his alarm was nothing more than a cake of Windsor soap, which a most portly and respectable sized rat had purloined from his bed-room, and was thus conveying, with no small labour, to his haunts below. The sudden relief thus given to his mind, induced him to make a motion that alarmed the industrious ghost, which, at one spring, reached a place of safety, leaving his booty behind—thus solving a mystery which had often led to a severe scolding to the servant for having appropriated to her own use divers pieces of soap and candle. On the next night the unfortunate freebooter made another excursion in search of plunder, and was again bearing off his spoil; but, unluckily, a fine tom cat having been called into requisition, he put an end to the life of the extraordinary entruder,and thus left our friend to the peaceable pursuit of his labours, not a little pleased to find that his doubts in the existence of goblins were still unshaken.
